sp.p: Marry, but it doth, sir, by your leave; your good days are past: though it be no matter for you, 'tis a matter for me, proper men are not so rife.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: O, but beware, how thou dost lay thy hand
Upon the high anointed of the lords
Oh, be advised ere thou dost begin:
Dispatch me straight, but meddle not with him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Friend, thy commission is to deal with me,
And I am he that hath deserved all:
The plot was laid to take away my life:
And here it is, I do entreat thee take it:
Yet for my sake, and as thou art a man,
Spare this my friend, that hither with me came?
I brought him forth, whereas he had not been,
But for good will to bear me company.
He left his friends, his country and his goods,
And came with me in most extremity.
O, if he should miscarry here and die,
Who is the cause of it, but only I?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Why that am I, let that never trouble thee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O no, 'tis I. Oh, had I now to give thee
The monarchy of all the spacious world
To save his life, I would bestow it on thee:
But I have nothing but these tears and prayer,
And the submission of a bent knee.Kneels.
O, if all this to mercy move they mind,
Spare him, in heaven thou shalt like mercy find.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: I am as hard to be moved as another, and yet methinks the strength of their persuasions stirs me a little.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My friend, if fear of the almighty power
Have power to move thee, we have said enough:
But if thy mind be movable with gold,
We have not presently to give it thee:
Yet to thyself thou mayst do greater good,
To keep thy hands still undefiled from blood:
For do but well consider with thyself,
When thou hast finished this outrageous act,
What horror still will haunt thee for the deed:
Think this again, that they which would incense
Thee for to be the butcher of their father,
When it is done, for fear it should be known,
Would make a means to rid thee from the world:
O, then art thou for ever tied in chains
Of everlasting torments to endure,
Even in the hottest hole of grisly hell,
Such pains, as never mortal tongue can tell.

div.stage: It thunders. He quakes, and lets fall the dagger next to Perillus.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O, heavens be thanked, he will spare my friend,
Now when thou wilt come make an end of me.

div.stage: He lets fall the other dagger.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: O, happy sight. He means to save my lord.
The King of heaven continue this good mind.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why stay'st thou to do execution?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: I am as wilful as you for your life:
I will not do it, now you do entreat me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Ah, now I see thou hast some spark of grace.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Beshrew you for it, you have put it in me:
The parlosest old men, that ere I heard.
Well, to be flat, I'll not meddle with you:
Here I found you, and here I'll leave you:
If any ask you why the case so stands?
Say that your tongue as were better than your hands.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Farewell. If ever we together me,
It shall go hard, but I will thee regreet.
Courage, my lord, the worst is overpast;
Let us give thanks to God, and hie us hence.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou art deceived; for I am passed the best,
And know not whither for to go from hence:
Death had been better welcome unto me,
Then longer life to add more misery.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: It were not good to return from whence we came,
Unto your daughter Ragan back again.
Now let us go to France, unto Cordella,
Your youngest daughter, doubtless she will succour you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O, how can I persuade myself of that,
Since the other two are quite devoid of love;
To whom I was so kind, as that my gifts,
Might make them love me, if 'twere nothing else?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: No worldly gifts, but grace from God on high,
Doth nourish virtue and true charity.
Remember well what words Cordella spoke,
What time you asked her, how she loved your grace.
She said, her love unto you was as much,
As ought a child to bear unto her father.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But she did find, my love was not to her,
As should a father bear unto a child.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: That makes not her love to be any less,
If she do love you as a child should do:
You have tried two, try one more for my sake,
I'll never entreat you further trial make.
Remember well the dream you had of late,
And think what comfort it foretells to us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come, truest friend, that ever man possessed,
I know thou counselst all things for the best:
If this third daughter play a kinder part,
It comes of God, and not of my desert.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: There is of late news come unto the court,
That old lord Leir remains in Cambria:
I'll hie me thither presently, to impart
My letters and my message unto him.
I never was less welcome to a place
In all my life time, than I have been hither,
Especially unto the stately Queen,
Who would not cast one gracious look on me,
But still with lowering and suspicious eyes,
Would take exceptions at each word I spoke,
And fain she would have undermined me,
To know what my ambassage did import:
But she is like to hop without her hope,
And in this matter for to want her will,
Though (By report) she'll have't in all things else.
Well, I will post away for Cambria:
Within these few days I hope to be there,

div.stage: Enter the King and Queen of Gallia, and Mumford.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: By this, our father understands our mind,
And our kind greetings sent to him of late;
Therefore my mind presageth ere't be long,
We shall receive from Britain happy news.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: I fear, my sister will dissuade his mind;
For she to me hath always been unkind.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fear not, my love, since that we know the worst,
The last means helps, if that we miss the first:
If he'll not come to Gallia unto us,
Then we will sail to Britain unto him.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: Well, if I once see Britain again,
I have sworn, I'll never come home without my wench,
And I'll not be forsworn,
I'll rather never come home while I live.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Are you sure, Mumford, she is a maid still?

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: Nay, I'll not swear she is a maid, but she goes for one:
I'll take her at all adventures, if I can get her.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Ay, that's well put in.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: Well put in: nay, it was ill put in; for had it
Been as well put in, as ere I put in, in my days,
I would have made her follow me to France.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Nay, you'd have been so kind, as take her with you,
Or else, were I as she,
I would have been so loving, as I'd stay behind you:
Yet I must confess, you are a very proper man,
And able to make a wench do more than she would do.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: Well, I have a pair of slops for the nonce,
Will hold all your mocks.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay, we see you have a handsome hose.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Ay, and of the newest fashion.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.p: More bobs, more: put them in still, they'll serve instead of bombast, yet put not in too many, lest the seams crack, and they fly out amongst you again: you must not think to outface me so easily in my mistress quarrel, who if I see once again, ten team of horses shall not draw me away, till I have full and whole possession.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ay, but one team and a cart will serve the turn.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Not only for him, but also for his wench.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: Well, you are two to one, I'll give you over:
And since I see you so pleasantly disposed,
Which indeed is but seldom seen, I'll claim
A promise of you, which you shall not deny me:
For promise is debt, and by this hand you promised it me.
Therefore you owe it me, and you shall pay it me,
Or I'll sue you upon an action of unkindness.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Prithee, lord Mumford, what promise did I make thee?

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: Faith, nothing but this,
That the next fair weather, which is very now,
You would go in progress down to the sea side,
Which is very near.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Faith, in this motion I will join with thee,
And be a mediator to my Queen.
Prithee, my love, let this march go forward,
My mind foretells, 'twill be a lucky voyage.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Entreaty needs not, where you may command,
So you be pleased, I am right well content:
Yet, as the sea I much desire to see;
So am I most unwilling to be seen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We'll go disguised, all unknown to any.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Howsoever you make one, I'll make another.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: And I the third: o, I am overjoyed!
See what love is, which getteth with a word,
What all the world besides could never obtain!
But what disguises shall we have, my lord?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fayth thus: my Queen and I will be disguised,
Like a plain country couple, and you shall be Roger
Our man, and wait upon us: or if you will,
You shall go first, and we will wait on you.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: 'Twere more than time; this device is excellent.
Come le us about it.

div.stage: Enter Cambria and Ragan, with nobles.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What strange mischance or unexpected hap
Hath thus deprived us of our father's presence?
Can no man tell us what's become of him,
With whom we did converse not two days since?
My lords, let everywhere light-horse be sent,
To scour about through all our regiment.
Dispatch a post immediately to Cornwall,
To see if any news by of him there;
Myself will make a strict inquiry here,
And all about our cities near at hand,
Till certain news of his abode be brought.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: All sorrow is but counterfeit to mine,
Whose lips are almost sealed up with grief:
Mine is the substance, whilst they do but seem
To weep the less, which tears cannot redeem.
Oh, never was heard so strange a misadventure,
A thing so far beyond the reach of sense,
Since no man's reason in the cause can enter.
What hath removed my father thus from hence?
O, I do fear some charm or invocation
Of wicked spirits, or infernal fiends,
Stirred by Cordella, moves this innovation,
And brings my father timeless to his end.
But might I know, that the detested witch
Were certain cause of this uncertain ill,
Myself to France would go in some disguise,
And with these nails scratch out her hateful eyes:
For since I am deprived of my father,
I loathe my life, and wish my death the rather.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The heavens are just, and hate impiety,
And will (No doubt) reveal such heinous crimes:
Censure not any, till you know the right:
Let him be judge, that bringeth truth to light.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: O, but my grief, like to a swelling tide,
Exceeds the bounds of common patience:
Nor can I moderate my tongue so much,
To conceal them, whom I hold in suspect.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: This matter shall be sifted: if it be she,
A thousand Frances shall not harbour her.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: All happiness unto the Cambrian King.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Welcome, my friend, from whence is thy ambassage?

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: I came from Gallia, unto Cornwall sent,
With letters to your honourable father,
Whom there not finding, as I did expect,
I was directed hither to repair.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: Frenchman, what is thy message to my father?

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: My letters, madam, will import the same,
Which my commission is for to deliver.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: In his absence you may trust us with your letters.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: I must perform my charge in such a manner,
As I have strict commandment from the King.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: There is good packing twixt your King and you:
You need not hither come to ask for him,
You know where he is better than ourselves.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: Madam, I hope, not far off.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Hath the young murderess, your outrageous Queen,
No means to colour her detested deeds,
In finishing my guiltless father's days,
(Because he gave her nothing to her dowry)
But by the colour of a feigned ambassage,
To send him letters hither to our court?
Go carry them to them that sent them hither,
And bid them keep their scrolls unto themselves:
They cannot blind us with such slight excuse,
To smother up so monstrous vild abuse.
And were it not, it is 'gainst law of arms,
To offer violence to a messenger,
We would inflict such torments on thyself,
As should enforce thee to reveal the truth.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: Madam, your threats no whit appall my mind,
I know my conscience guiltless of this act;
My King and Queen, I dare be sworn, are free
From any thought of such impiety:
And therefore, madam, you have done them wrong,
And ill beseeming with a sister's love,
Who in mere duty tender him as much,
As ever you respected him for dowry.
The King your husband will not say as much.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I will suspend my judgement for a time,
Till more appearance give us further light:
Yet to be plain, your coming doth enforce
A great suspicion to our doubtful mind,
And that you do resemble, to be brief,
Him that first robs, and then cries, stop the thief.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: Pray God some near you have not done the like.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: Hence, saucy mate, reply no more to us;
For law of arms shall not protect thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Ambassador
sp.l: Never was I offered such discourtesy;
God and my King, I trust, ere it be long,
Will find a mean to remedy this wrong,

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: How shall I live, to suffer this disgrace,
At every base and vulgar peasant's hands?
It ill befitteth my imperial state,
To be thus used, and no man take my part.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What should I do? infringe the law of arms,
Were to my everlasting obloquy:
But I will take revenge upon his master,
Which sent him hither, to delude us thus.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: Nay, if you put up this, be sure, ere long,
Now that my father thus is made away.
She'll come and claim a third part of your crown,
As due unto her by inheritance.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: But I will prove her title to be naught
But shame, and the reward of parricide,
And make her an example to the world,
For after-ages to admire her penance.
This will I do, as I am Cambria's King,
Or lose my life, to prosecute revenge.
Come, first let's learn what news is of our father,
And then proceed, as best occasion fits.

div.stage: Enter Leir, Perillus, and two mariners, in sea-gownes and sea-caps.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My honest friends, we are ashamed to show
The great extremity of our present state,
In that at this time we are brought so low,
That we want money for to pay our passage.
The truth is so, we met with some good fellows,
A little before we came aboard your ship,
Which stripped us quite of all the coin we had,
And left us not a penny in our purses:
Yet wanting money, we will use the mean,
To see you satisfied to the uttermost.

sp.speaker: 1. Mar.
sp.l: Here's a good gown, 'twould become me passing well,
I should be fine in it.

sp.speaker: 2. Mar.
sp.l: Here's a good cloak, I marvel how I should look in it,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Faith, had we others to supply their room,
Though never so mean, you willingly should have them.

sp.speaker: 1. Mar.
sp.l: Do you hear, sir? you look like an honest man;
sp.p: I'll not stand to do you a pleasure: here's a good strong motley gaberdine, cost me xiv. good shillings at Billingsgate, give me your gown for it, and your cap for mine, and I'll forgive your passage.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: With all my heart, and xx. thanks.

sp.speaker: 2. Mar.
sp.p: Do you hear, sir? you shall have a better match than he, because you are my friend: here is a good sheeps russet sea-gown, will bide more stress, I warrant you, then two of his, yet for you seem to be an honest gentleman, I am content to change it for your cloak, and ask you nothing for your passage more.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My own I willingly would change with thee,
And think myself indebted to thy kindness:
But would my friend might keep his garment still.
My friend, I'll give thee this new doublet, if thou wilt
Restore his gown unto him back again.

sp.speaker: 1. Mar.
sp.p: Nay, if I do, would I might never eat powdered beef and mustard more, nor drink can of good liquor whilst I live. My friend, you have small reason to seek to hinder me of my bargain: but the best is, a bargain's a bargain.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Kind friend, it is much better as it is;
For by this means we may escape unknown;
Till time and opportunity do fit.

sp.speaker: 2. Mar.
sp.l: Hark, hark, they are laying their heads together,
They'll repent them of their bargain anon,
'Twere best for us to go while we are well.

sp.speaker: 1. Mar.
sp.l: God be with you, sir, for your passage back again,
I'll use you as unreasonable as another.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I know thou wilt; but we hope to bring ready money
With us, when we come back again.
Were ever men in this extremity,
In a strange country, and devoid of friends,
And not a penny for to help ourselves?
Kind friend, what thinkst thou will become of us?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Be of good cheer, my lord, I have a doublet,
Will yield us money enough to serve our turns,
Until we come unto your daughter's court:
And then, I hope, we shall find friends enough.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ah, kind Perillus, that is it I fear,
And makes me faint, or ever I come there.
Can kindness spring out of ingratitude?
Or love be reaped, where hatred hath been sown?
Can henbane join in league with mithridate?
Or sugar grow in wormwood's bitter stalk?
It cannot be, they are too opposite:
And so am I to any kindness here.
I have thrown wormwood on the sugared youth,
And like to henbane poisoned the fount,
Whence flowed the mithridate of a child's goodwill:
Ay, like an envious thorn, have pricked the heart,
And turned sweet grapes, to sour unrelished sloes:
The causelesseire of my respectless breast,
Hath soured the sweet milk of dame nature's paps:
My bitter words have galled her honey thoughts,
And weeds of rancour choked the flower of grace.
Then what remainder is of any hope,
But all our fortunes will go quite aslope?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Fear not, my lord, the perfect good indeed,
Can never be corrupted by the bad:
A new fresh vessel still retains the taste
Of that which first is poured into the same:
And therefore, though you name yourself the thorn,
The weed, the gall, the henbane and the wormwood;
Yet she'll continue in her former state,
The honey, milk, grape, sugar, mithridate.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou pleasing orator unto me in woe,
Cease to beguile me with thy hopeful speeches
Oh join with me, and think of naught but crosses,
And then we'll one lament another's losses.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why, say the worst, the worst can be but death,
And death is better than for to despair:
Then hazard death, which may convert to life;
Banish despair, which brings a thousand deaths.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O'ercome with thy strong arguments, I yield,
To be directed by thee, as thou wilt:
As thou yield'st comfort to my crazed thoughts,
Would I could yield the like unto thy body,
Which is full weak, I know, and ill apaid,
For want of fresh meat and due sustenance.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Alack, my lord, my heart doth bleed, to think
That you should be in such extremity.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come, let us go, and see what God will send;
When all means fail, he is the surest friend.

div.stage: Enter the Gallian King and Queens, and Mumford, with a basket, disguised like country folk.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This tedious journey all on foot, sweet love,
Cannot be pleasing to your tender joints,
Which never were used to these toilsome walks.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: I never in my life took more delight
In any journey, than I do in this:
Ic did me good, whenas we happed to light
Amongst the merry crew of country folk,
To see what industry and pains they took,
To win them commendations amongst their friends.
Lord, how they labour to bestir themselves,
And in their quirks to go beyond the moon,
And so take on them with such antic fits,
That one would think they were beside their wits!
Come away, Roger, with your basket.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: Soft, dame, here comes a couple of old youths,
I must needs make myself fat-with testing at them.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Nay, prithee do not, they do seem to be
sp.stage: Enter Leir and Perillus very faintly.
sp.l: Men much o'ergone with grief and misery.
Let's stand aside, and harken what they say.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ah, my Perillus, now I see we both
Shall end our days in this untrustful soil.
O, I do faint for want of sustenance:
And thou, I know, in little better case.
No gentle tree affords one taste of fruit,
To comfort us, until we meet with men:
No lucky path conducts our luckless steps
Unto a place where any comfort dwells.
Sweet rest betide unto our happy souls;
For here I see our bodies must have end.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Ah, my dear lord, how doth my heart lament,
To see you brought to this extremity!
O, if you love me, as you do profess,
Or ever thought well of me in my life,
Feed on this flesh, whose veins are not so dry,
But there is virtue left to comfort you,
Oh, feed on this, if this will do you good,
I'll smile for joy, to see you suck my blood.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I am no cannibal, that I should delight
To slake my hungry jaws with humane flesh:
I am no devil, or ten times worse than so,
To suck the blood of such a peerless friend.
O, do not think that I respect my life
So dear, as I do thy loyal love.
Ah, Britain, I shall never see thee more,
That hast unkindly banished thy King:
And yet not thou dost make me to complain,
But they which were more near to me than thou.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What do I hear: this lamentable voice,
Methinks , ere now I oftentimes have heard.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ah, Gonorill, was half my kingdom's gift
The cause that thou didst seek to have my life:
Ah, cruel Ragan, did I give thee all,
And all could not suffice without my blood?
Ah, poor Cordella, did I give thee naught,
Nor never shall be able for to give?
O, let me warn all ages that ensueth,
How they trust flattery, and reject the truth.
Well, unkind girls, I here forgive you both,
Yet the just heavens will hardly do the like;
And only crave forgiveness at the end
Of good Cordella, and of thee, my friend;
Of God, whose majesty I have offended,
By my transgression many thousand ways:
Of her, dear heart, whom I for no occasion
Turned out of all, through flatterer's persuasion:
Of thee, kind friend, who but for me, I know,
Hadst never come unto this place of woe.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Alack, that ever I should live to see
My noble father in this misery.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sweet love, reveal not what thou art as yet,
Until we know the ground of this ill.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O, but some meat, some meat: do you not see,
How near they are to death for want of food?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Lord, which didst help they servants at their need,
Or now or never send us help with speed.
O comfort, comfort! yonder is a banquet,
And men and women, my lord: be of good cheer;
For I see comfort coming very near.
O my lord, a banquet, and men and women!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O, let kind pity mollify their hearts,
That they may help us in our great extremes.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: God save you, friends; and if this blessed banquet
Affordeth any food or sustenance,
Even for his sake that saved us all from death,
Vouchsafe to save us from the gripe of famine.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Here father, sit and eat, here, sit and drink:
sp.stage: She bringeth him to the table
sp.l: And would it were far better for your sakes.

div.stage: Perillus takes Leir by the hand to the table.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I'll give you thanks anon: my friend doth faint,
And needeth present comfort.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: I warrant, he never stays to say grace:
Oh, there's no sauce to a good stomach.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: The blessed god of heaven hath thought upon us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The thanks be his, and these kind courteous folk,
By whose humanity we are preserved.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And may that draught be unto him, as was
That which old Aeson drank, which did renew
His withered age, and made him young again.
And may that meat be unto him, as was
That which Elias ate, in strength whereof
He walked forty days, and never fainted.
Shall I conceal me longer from my father?
Or shall I manifest myself to him?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Forbear a while, until his strength return,
Lest being overjoyed with seeing thee,
His poor weak senses should forsake their office,
And so our cause of joy be turned to sorrow.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What cheer, my lord? how do you feel yourself?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Methinks , I never ate such savoury meat:
It is as pleasant as the blessed manna,
That reigned from heaven amongst the Israelites:
It hath recalled my spirits home again,
And made me fresh, as erst I was before.
But how shall we congratulate their kindness?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: In faith, I know no how sufficiently;
But the best mean that I can think on, is this:
I'll offer them my doublet in requital;
For we have nothing else to spare.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay, stay, Perillus, for they shall have mine.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pardon, my lord, I swear they shall have mine.

div.stage: Perillus proffers his doublet: they will not take it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ah, who would think such kindness should remain
Among such strange and unacquainted men:
And that such hate should harbour in the breast
Of those, which have occasion to be best?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Ah, good old father, tell to me thy grief,
I'll sorrow with thee, if not add relief.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ah, good young daughter, I may call thee so;
For thou art like a daughter I did owe.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Do you not owe her still? what, is she dead?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No, God forbid: but all my interest's gone,
By showing myself too much unnatural:
So have I lost the title of a father,
And me be called a stranger to her rather.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Your title's good still; for 'tis always known,
A man may do as him list with his own.
But have you but one daughter then in all?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yes, I have more by two, than would I had.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O, say not so, but rather see the end:
They that are bad, may have the grace to mend:
But how have they offended you so much?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: If from the first I should relate the cause,
'T would make a heart of adamant to weep;
And thou, poor soul, kind-hearted as thou art,
Dost weep already, ere I do begin.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: For god's love tell it, and when you have done,
I'll tell the reason why I weep so soon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The know this first, I am a Britain born,
And had three daughters by one loving wife:
And though I say it, of beauty they were sped;
Especially the youngest of the three,
For her perfections hardly matched could be:
On these I doted with a jealous love,
And thought to try which of them loved me best,
By asking them, which would do most for me?
The first and second flattered me with words,
And vowed they loved me better than their lives:
The youngest said, she loved me as a child
Might dom: her answer I esteemed most vild,
And presently in an outrageous mood,
I turned her from me to go sink or swim:
And all I had, even to the very clothes,
I gave in dowry with the other two:
And she that best deserved the greatest share,
I gave her nothing, but disgrace and care.
Now mark the sequel: when I had done thus,
I sojourned in my eldest daughter's house,
Where for a time I was entreated well,
And lived in state sufficing my content:
But every day her kindness did grow cold,
Which I with patience put up well enough,
And seemed not to see the things I saw:
But at the last she grew so far incensed
With moody fury, and with causeless hate,
That in most vild and contumelious terms,
She bade me pack, and harbour somewhere else.
Then was I fain for refuge to repair
Unto my other daughter for relief,
Who gave me pleasing and most courteous words;
But in her actions showed herself so sore,
As never any daughter did before:
She prayed me in a morning out betime,
To go to a thicket two miles from the court,
Pointing that there she would come talk with me:
There she had set a shag-haired murdering wretch,
To massacre my honest friend and me.
Then judge yourself, although my tale be brief,
If ever man had greater cause of grief.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nor never like impiety was done,
Since the creation of the world begun.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And now I am constrained to seek relief
Of her, to whom I have been so unkind;
Whose censure, if it do award me death,
I must confess she pays me but my due:
But if the show a loving daughter's part,
It comes of God and her, not my desert.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: No doubt she will, I dare be sworn she will.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How know you that, not knowing what she is?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Myself a father have a great way hence,
Used me as ill as ever you did her;
Yet, that his reverend age I once might see,
I'd creep along, to meet him on my knee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O, no men's children are unkind but mine.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Condemn not all, because of others crime:
But look, dear father, look, behold and see
Thy loving daughter speaketh unto thee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O, stand thou up, it is my part to kneel,
And ask forgiveness for my former faults.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O, if you wish I should enjoy my breath,
Dear father rise, or I receive my death.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then I will rise, to satisfy your mind,
But kneel again, till pardon be resigned.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I pardon you: the word beseems not me:
But I do say so, for to ease your knee.
You gave me life, you were the cause that I
Am what I am, who else had never been.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But you gave life to me and to my friend,
Whose days had else, had an untimely end.

sp.speaker: Cour
sp.l: You brought me up, whenas I was but young,
And far unable for to help myself.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I cast thee forth, whenas thou wast but young,
And far unable for to help thyself.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: God, world and nature say I do you wrong,
That can endure to see you kneel so long.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Let me break off this loving controversy,
Which doth rejoice my very soul to see.
Good father, rise, she is your loving daughter,
And honours you with as respective duty,
As if you were the monarch of the world.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: But I will never rise from off my knee,
Until I have your blessing, and your pardon
Of all my faults committed any way,
From my first birth unto this present day.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The blessing, which the god of Abraham gave
Unto the tribe of Juda, light on thee,
And multiply thy days, that thou mayst see
Thy children's children prosper after thee.
Thy faults, which are just none that I do know,
God pardon on high, and I forgive below.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Now is my heart at quiet, and doth leap
Within my breast, for joy of this good hap:
And now (Dear father) welcome to our court,
And welcome (Kind Perillus) unto me,
Mirror of virtue and true honesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O, he hath been the kindest friend to me,
That ever man had in adversity.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My tongue doth fail, to say what heart doth think,
I am so ravished with exceeding joy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: All you have spoke: now let me speak my mind,
And in few words much matter here conclude:
If ere my heart do harbour any joy,
Or true content repose within my breast,
Till I have rooted out this viperous sect,
And repossessed my father of his crown,
Let me be counted for the periurdst man,
That ever spoke word since the world began.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: Let me pray to, that never prayed before;
If ere I resalute the British earth,
(As (Ere't be long) I do presume I shall)
And do return from thence without my wench,
Let me be gelded for my recompense.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come, let's to arms for to redress this wrong:
Till I am there, methinks , the time seems long.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: I feel a hell of conscience in my breast,
Tormenting me with horror for my fact,
And makes me in an agony of doubt,
For fear the world should find my dealing out.
The slave whom I appointed for the act,
I never set eye upon the peasant since:
Oh, could I get him for to make him sure,
My doubts would cease, and I should rest secure.
But if the old men, with persuasive words,
Have saved their lives, and made him to relent;
Then are they fled unto the court of France,
And like a trumpet manifest my shame.
A shame on these white-livered slaves, say I,
That with fair words so soon are overcome.
O God, that I had been but made a man;
Or that my strength were equal with my will!
These foolish men are nothing but mere pity,
And melt as butter doth against the sun.
Why should they have pre-eminence over us,
Since we are creatures of more brave resolve?
I swear, I am quite out of charity
With all the heartless men in Christendom.
A pox upon them, when they are afraid
To give a stab, or slit a paltry windpipe,
Which are so easy matters to be done.
Well, had I thought the slave would serve me so,
Myself would have been executioner:
'Tis now undone, and if that it be known,
I'll make as good shift as I can for one.
He that repines at me, howe'er it stands,
'Twere best for him to keep him from my hands.

div.stage: Sound drums and trumpets: enter the Gallian King, Leir, Mumford and the army.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thus have we brought our army to the sea,
Whereas our ships are ready to receive us:
The wind stands fair, and we in four hours sail,
May easily arrive on British shore,
Where unexpected we may them surprise,
And gain a glorious victory with ease.
Wherefore, my loving countrymen, resolve,
Since truth and justice fighteth on our sides,
That we shall march with conquest where we go.
Myself will be as forward as the first,
And step by step march with the hardiest wight:
And not the meanest soldier in our camp
Shall be in danger, but I'll second him.
To you, my lord, we give the whole command
Of all the army, next unto ourself,
Not doubting of you, but you will extend
Your wonted valour in this needful case,
Encouraging the rest to do the like,
By your approved magnanimity.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: My liege, 'tis needless to spur a willing horse,
That's apt enough to run himself to death:
For here I swear by that sweet saints bright eye,
Which are the stars, which guide me to good hap,
Either to see my old lord crowned anew,
Or in his cause to bid the world adieu.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thanks, good lord Mumford, 'tis more of your good will,
Than any merit or desert in me.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: And now to you, my worthy country men,
Ye valiant race of Genovestan Gauls,
Surnamed Red-thanks, for your chivalry,
Because you fight up to the thanks in blood;
Show yourselves now to be right Gauls indeed,
And be so bitter on your enemies,
That they may say, you are as bitter as gall.
Gall them, brave shot, with your artillery:
Gall them, brave halberts, with your sharp point bills,
Each in their pointed place, not one, but all,
Fight for the credit of yourselves and Gaul.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then what should more persuasion need to those,
That rather with to deal, than hear of blows?
Let's to our ships, and it that God permit,
In four hours sail, I hope we shall be there.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: And in five hours more, I make no doubt,
But we shall bring our wished desires about.

div.stage: Enter a captain of the watch, and two watchmen.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: My honest friends, it is your turn tonight ,
To watch in this place, near about the beacon.
And vigilantly have regard,
If any fleet of ships past hitherward:
Which it you do, your office is to fire
The beacon presently, and raise the town.

sp.speaker: 1. Wat.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ay, fear nothing; we know our charge, I warrant: I have been a watchman about this beacon this xxx. year, and yet I never see it stir, but stood as quietly as might be.

sp.speaker: 2. Wat.
sp.p: Faith neighbour, and you'll follow my vice, instead of watching the beacon, we'll go to goodman Gennings, and watch a pot of ale and a rasher of bacon: and if we do not drink ourselves drunk, then so; I warrant, the beacon will see us when we come out again.

sp.speaker: 1. W.
sp.p: Ay, but how if somebody excuse us to the captain?

sp.speaker: 2. W.
sp.p: I is no matter, I'll prove by good reason that we watch the beacon: ass for example.

sp.speaker: 1. W.
sp.p: I hope you do not call me ass by craft, neighbour.

sp.speaker: 2. W.
sp.p: No, no, but for example: say here stands the pot of ale, that's the beacon.

sp.speaker: 1. W.
sp.p: Ay, ay, 'tis a very good beacon.

sp.speaker: 2. W.
sp.p: Well, say here stands your nose, that's the fire.

sp.speaker: 1. W.
sp.p: Indeed I must confess, 'tis somewhat red.

sp.speaker: 2. W.
sp.p: I see come marching in a dish, half a score pieces of salt bacon.

sp.speaker: 1. W.
sp.p: I understand your meaning, that's as much to say, half a score ships.

sp.speaker: 2 W.
sp.p: True, you construe right; presently, like a faithful watch man, I fire the beacon; and call up the town.

sp.speaker: 1. W.
sp.p: Ay, that's as much as to say, you set your nose to the pot, and drink up the drink.

sp.speaker: 2. W.
sp.p: You are in the right; come, let's go fire the beacon.

div.stage: Enter the King of Gallia with a still march, Mumford and soldiers,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now march our ensigns on the British earth,
And we are near approaching to the town:
Then look about you, valiant countrymen,
And we shall finish this exploit with ease.
Th'ihabitants of this mistrustful place,
Are dead asleep, as men that are secure:
Here shall we skirmish but with naked men,
Devoid of sense, new waked from a dream,
That know not what our coming doth pretend,
Till they do feel our meaning on their skins:
Therefore assail: God and our right for us.

div.stage: Alarum, with men and women half naked: enter two captains without doublets, with swords.

sp.speaker: 1. Captain
sp.l: Where are these villains that were set to watch,
And fire the beacon, if occasion served,
That thus have suffered us to be surprised,
And never given notice to the town?
We are betrayed, and quite devoid of hope,
By any means to fortify ourselves.

sp.speaker: 2. Captain
sp.p: 'Tis ten to one the peasants are o'ercome with drink and sleep, and so neglect their charge.

sp.speaker: 1. Captain
sp.p: A whirlwind carry them quick to a whirlpool, that there the slaves may drink their bellies full.

sp.speaker: 2. Captain
sp.p: This 'tis, to have the beacon so near the alehouse.

div.stage: Enter the watchmen drunk, with each a pot.

sp.speaker: 1. Captain
sp.p: Out on ye, villains, whither run you now?

sp.speaker: 1. Wat.
sp.p: To fire the town, and call up the beacon.

sp.speaker: 2 Wat.
sp.p: No, no, sir, to fire the beacon.

sp.speaker: 2. Captain
sp.p: What, with a pot of ale, you drunken rogues?

sp.speaker: 1. Captain
sp.l: You'll fire the beacon, when the town is lost:
I'll teach you how to tend your office better.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.p: Yield, yield, yield.

sp.speaker: 1. Wat.
sp.l: Reel? no, we do not reel:
You may lack a pot of ale ere you die.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.p: But in mean space, I answer, you want none. Well, there's no dealing with you, you're tall men, and well weaponed, I would there were no worse than you in the town.

sp.speaker: 2. Wat.
sp.p: 'A speaks like an honest man, my cholers passed already. Come, neighbour, let's go.

sp.speaker: 1. Wat.
sp.p: Nay, first let's see and we can stand.

div.stage: Alarum, excursions, Mumford after them, and some half naked, enter the Gallian King, Leir, Mumford, Cordella, Perillus, and soldiers, with the chief of the town bound.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fear not, my friends, you shall receive no hurt,
If you'll subscribe unto your lawful King,
And quite revoke your fealty from Cambria,
And from aspiring Cornwall too, whose wives
Have practised treason 'gainst their father's life.
We come in justice of your wronged King,
And do intend no harm at all to you,
So you submit unto your lawful King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Kind countrymen, it grieves me, that perforce,
I am constrained to use extremities.

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.l: Long have you here been looked for, good my lord,
And wished for by a general consent:
And had we known your highness had arrived,
We had not made resistance to your grace:
And now, my gracious lord, you need not doubt,
But all the country will yield presently,
Which since your absence have been greatly taxed,
For to maintain their overswelling pride.
We'll presently send word to all our friends;
When they have notice, they will come apace.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thanks, loving subjects; and thanks, worthy son,
Thanks, my kind daughter, thanks to you, my lord,
Who willingly adventured have your blood,
(Without desert) to do me so much good.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: O, say not so:
I have been much beholding to your grace:
I must confess, I have been in some skirmishes,
But I was never in the like to this:
For where I was wont to meet with armed men,
I was now encountered with naked women,

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: We that are feeble, and want use of arms,
Will pray to God, to shield you from all harms.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The while your hands do manage ceaseless toil,
Our hearts shall pray, the foes may have the foil.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: We'll fast and pray, whilst you for us do fight,
That victory may prosecute the right.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Methinks , your words do amplify (My friends)
And add fresh vigour to my willing limbs:
But hark, I hear the adverse drum approach.
God and our right, saint Denis, and saint George,

div.stage: Enter Cornwall, Cambria, Gonorill, Ragan, and the army.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: Presumptuous King of Gauls, how darest thou
Presume to enter on our British shore?
And more than that, to take our towns perforce,
And draw our subjects' hearts from their true King?
Be suit to buy it at as dear a price,
As ere you bought presumption in your lives.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O'erdaring Cornwall, know, we came in right.
And just revengement of the wronged King,
Whose daughters there, fell vipers as they are,
Have sought to murder and deprive of life:
But God protected him from all their spite,
And we are come in justice of his right.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Nor he nor thou have any interest here,
But what you win and purchase with the sword.
Thy slanders to our noble virtuous Queens,
We'll in the battle thrust them down thy throat,
Except for fear of our revenging hands,
Thou fly to sea, as not secure on lands.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: Welshman, I'll so f●●rit you ere night for that word,
That you shall have no mind to crake so well this twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: They lie, that say, we sought our father's death.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: 'Tis merely forged for a colours sake,
To set a gloss on your invasion.
Methinks , an old man ready for to die,
Should be ashamed to breach so foul a lie.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Fie shameless sister, so devoid of grace,
To call our father liar to his face.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Peace (Puritan) dissembling hypocrite,
Which art so good, that thou wilt prove stark naught:
Anon, whenas I have you in my fingers,
I'll make you wish yourself in purgatory.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Nay, peace thou monster, shame unto thy sex:
Thou fiend in likeness of a humane creature.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: I never heard a fouler spoken man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Out on thee, viper, scum, filthy parricide,
More odious to my sight then is a toad,
Knowest thou these letters?

div.stage: She snatches them and tears them.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: Think you to outface me with your paltry scrolls?
You come to drive my husband from his right,
Under the colour of a forged letter.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Whoever heard the like impiety?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: You are our debtor of more patience:
We were more patient when we stayed for you,
Within the thicket two long hours and more.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: What hours? what thicket?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: There, where you sent your servant with your letters,
Sealed with your hand, to send us both to heaven,
Where, as I think, you never mean to come.

sp.speaker: Rag.
sp.l: Alas, you are grown a child again with age,
Or else your senses dote for want of sleep.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Indeed you made us rise betimes, you know,
Yet had a care we should sleep where you bade us stay,
But never wake more till the latter day.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Peace, peace, old fellow, thou art sleepy still.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: Faith, and if you reason till tomorrow,
You get no other answer at their hands.
'Tis pity two such good faces
Should have so little grace between them.
Well, let us see if their husbands with their hands,
Can do as much, as they do with their tongues.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Ay, with their swords they'll make your tongue unsay
What they have said, or else they'll cut them out.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To't, gallants, to't, let's not stand brawling thus.

div.stage: Sound alarum: excursions ▪ Mumford must chase Cambria away: then cease. Enter Cornwall.

sp.speaker: Cornwall
sp.l: The day is lost, our friends do all revolt,
And join against us with the adverse part:
There is no means of safety but by flight,
And therefore I'll to Cornwall with my Queen.

sp.speaker: Cam
sp.p: I think, there is a devil in the camp hath haunted me today: he hath so tired me, that in a manner I can fight no more.
Zounds, here he comes, I'll take me to my horse.

div.stage: Mumford follows him to the door, and returns.

sp.speaker: Mum.
sp.l: Farewell (Welshman) give thee but thy due,
Thou hast a light and nimble pair of legs:
Thou are more in debt to them then to thy hands:
But if I meet thee once again today,
I'll cut them off, and set them to a better heart.

div.stage: Alarms and excursions, then sound victory. Enter Leir, Perillus, King, Cordella, and Mumford.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thanks be to God, your foes are overcome,
And you again possessed of your right.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: First to the heavens, next, thanks to you, my son,
By whose good means I repossess the same:
Which if it please you to accept yourself,
With all my heart I will resign to you:
For it is yours by right, and none of mine.
First, have you raised, at your own charge, a power
Of valiant soldiers; (This comes all from you)
Next have you ventured your own persons scathe.
And lastly, (Worthy Gallia never stained)
My kingly title I by thee have gained.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thank heavens, not me, my zeal to you is such,
Command my utmost, I will never grutch.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: He that with all kind love entreats his Queen,
Will not be to her father unkind seen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ah, my Cordella, now I call to mind,
The modest answer, which I took unkind:
But now I see, I am no whit beguiled,
Thou lovedst me dear, and as ought a child.
And thou (Perillus) partner once in woe,
Thee to requite, the best I can, I'll do:
Yet all I can, ay, were it never so much,
Were not sufficient, thy true love is such.
Thanks (Worthy Mumford) to thee last of all,
Not greeted last, 'cause thy desert was small;
No, thou hast lion-like laid on today,
Chasing the Cornwall King and Cambria;
Who with my daughters, daughters did I say?
To save their lives, the fugitives did play.
Come, son and daughter, who did me advance,
Repose with me awhile, and then for France.
